items.title: How to read the spec behind JavaScript
items.content:
#â€‹578 â€” February 25, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

What Are Wrapper Objects for JavaScript's PrimitiveÂ Values? â€” Dr. Axel talks about how primitive types like boolean and string have associated wrapper classes (e.g. Boolean and String) and demonstrates the value theyÂ provide.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

How to Read the ECMAScript Specification â€” Each time thereâ€™s a new ECMAScript spec we link to it - such as this draft ES2022 spec.. but who reads such a complex and intimidating document? This is a neat dig into how the spec ticks formatting wise and why the spec is worth a skim at theÂ least.

Timothy Gu

Learn the Fundamentals of Rx.js â€” This useful JavaScript library is great for managing events that happen over time, and in this detailed video course Steve Kinney covers what you need to know to make use of it â€” including observables, events, intervals, timers, operators, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

ğŸ“„ PDF:Â From JavaScript to Rust: A Book â€” A book that attempts to map common JavaScript workflows to the Rust ecosystem, if youâ€™ve been keen to pick up the increasingly popular systems language. Thereâ€™s also a GitHub repo with the source for theÂ book.

Jarrod Overson

Cheerp 2.7: Compile C++ to WebAssembly and JavaScript â€” The latest version of a unique tool (built upon the clang compiler) that provides JavaScript-C++ interoperability gains ES modules support and produces faster and smaller output thanÂ before.

Carlo Piovesan

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸŸ© Node 17.6.0 has been released with initial (and experimental) support for loading ES modules over HTTPS.

  • Glitch is a neat online app building environment well suited to JavaScript apps, and you can now deploy Glitch apps to DigitalOcean. They're also collaborating with Fastly.

  • The â–¶ï¸ story of TypeScript told in 6 minutes. And if you like this format, there's the â–¶ï¸ story of asynchronous JavaScript too!

RELEASES:

Playwright 1.19 â€“ Browser automation library.
neo.mjs 3.2.5 â€“ Web Worker enhanced frontend framework.
Jasmine 4.0.1 â€“ JS testing framework.
Resemble.js 4.1 â€“ Image analysis and comparison library.
eva.js 1.2.7 â€“ Front-end game engine.
History 5.3 â€“ Manage session history with JS.
qooxdoo 7.0 â€“ SPA framework we last mentioned 7 yrs ago(!)

ğŸ’» Jobs

Work Remotely Forever â€” When you join Toptal, you get the freedom of freelance with the security of full-time. Take control of your careerÂ today.
Toptal

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Fullstack Engineer (Remote, EU Timezones) â€” Weâ€™ve built a product thousands of people love (See Trustpilot if you donâ€™t believe us). We need your help with Node &Â TypeScript.
Feather

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Reliably Send an HTTP Request on Leaving a Page â€” Browsers donâ€™t guarantee to preserve open HTTP requests when changing pages but there are some mitigations or alternative approaches (e.g. beacons).

Alex MacArthur

How To Develop a Text Editor for the Web â€” The engineer at a company building a browser-based design tool reflects on some of the technical issues of producing a reliable text entryÂ widget.

Ilya Medvedev

3k+ Devs Completed the State of Frontend 2022 - It's Your Turn â€” 3k devs and counting - we need you too! Take 8 minutes click through the survey, and catch the outcomeÂ soon.

The Software House sponsor

Future JavaScript: A Look at Records and Tuples â€” Two years ago we mentioned the record and tuples proposal (two new deeply immutable primitive types for JS) had reached stage 2 at TC39. Itâ€™s still there.. but a polyfill brings them to BabelÂ users.

Johnny Simpson

You Can throw() Anything In JavaScript (And Other async/await Considerations) â€” The author experiments with throw and ends up questioning his mental model of errorÂ handling.

Ben Nadel

â–¶Â Â What is Responsible JavaScript? â€” The author of Responsible JavaScript talks about topics like responsible data usage, user experience, backwards compatibility, etc. (55Â minutes.)

Smashing Magazine Podcast podcast

How to Make a Data Dashboard with React Native

InfluxData sponsor

How to Use nextTick() in Vue â€” nextTick(callback) executes the callback when the DOM has beenÂ updated.

Dmitri Pavlutin

Optimizing Third-Party Script Loading in Next.js
Leena Sohoni and Houssein Djirdeh (Google)

â–¶Â Â 10 Things You Should Know About Lodash in 3 Minutes
EzBackend

Comparing Gatsby and Next.js
Alex Barashkov

Implementing the Game of Life with React, Hooks and Chakra-UI
Ruslan Elishaev

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Screenshot: No-Dependency Browser-Native Screenshot Library â€” Uses the MediaDevices API but provides an easier to use abstract for letting users take screenshots. GitHubÂ repo.

Tejas Kumar

Introducing FormKit: A Vue 3 Form Building Framework â€” A complete form building framework inspired by earlier work on Vue Formulate. GitHubÂ repo.

Justin Schroeder

Stylo: An Open Source WYSIWYG Rich Text Editor for JavaScript â€” Lightweight, no dependencies, and you can configure the default toolbar to suit your app's specificÂ needs.

David Dal Busco

More Cloud for Less Money â€” Vultr offers developers Cloud Compute instances as low as $2.50 per month. Try Vultr for 14 days with this freeÂ credit.

Vultr sponsor

Beam: Node.js-Powered and GitHub-Inspired Message Board forÂ Teams â€” Beam is a message board inspired by a similar proprietary system used for team communication at GitHub. GitHubÂ repo.

PlanetScale

Stockfish.js: A Chess Engine â€” Stockfish is a popular chess engine usually written in C++ but this project brings it into JS contexts by way ofÂ WebAssembly.

Nathan Rugg

ğŸ˜† Â Elevator.js: An Old Fashioned 'Scroll to Top'Â Button â€” Just a bitÂ ofÂ fun.
Tim Holman

enum-xyz: JavaScript Enums using Proxies â€” Fun little reader-submittedÂ idea.
Chase Fleming

items.title: The State of JS results are in
items.content:
#â€‹577 â€” February 18, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of JS 2021 Results â€” Despite saying 2021, the survey took place this January, so the results are up to date and represent the answers given by the 16,085 respondents. As with any survey or poll, be careful in how you interpret the results (many folks have noted problems around diversity or methodology) but nonetheless we always enjoy seeing the results from year to year and seeing what people have mentioned. Highlights:

  • esbuild was the tool with the largest year on year satisfaction growth.
  • 5.6% of respondents are using Deno.
  • Long standing libraries Axios, Lodash and Moment remain the most popular.
  • Syntax is by far the most popular podcast but there are 24 others in the list to check out.
  • TypeScript is by far the most common alternative 'flavor' of JavaScript, with Elm a distant second place.
  • Shawn 'swyx' Wang has a neat round up / conclusion post.

Sacha Greif

JavaScript Scratchpad for VS Code, Now with CodeÂ Stories â€” Quokka.js is the #1 tool for exploring and testing JavaScript. Code runs immediately as you type. The new Code Story Viewer provides a unique and highly efficient way of inspecting runtime values to see what your code is doing in a single continuousÂ view.

Wallaby.js sponsor

Express.js 5.0 Now in Beta â€” Considering that the first alpha of 5.0 was over seven years ago, this is a big step for the still wildly popular and influential Node.js Web app library. Thereâ€™s also thorough docs of the 5.x APIÂ here.

Express.js Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Microsoft's Angela Zhang writes about how Microsoft has been improving React Native's ability to call Windows APIs and how it's already being used in part of Windows 11.

  • Version 100 of both Chrome and Firefox will soon be with us, so it's time to think about if your code can cope and to test things out.

  • ğŸ‘¾ Enjoyed the Wordle word game? Jazle is Wordle but for JavaScript package/project names.

  • Joyent has transferred the Node.js trademarks to the OpenJS Foundation.

  • Google has unveiled the next version of its Cloud Functions serverless platform with longer function running times, bigger instances, and more.

  • ESLint 8.9.0 has landed with a new es2022 environment added.

RELEASES:

Next.js 12.1
TypeScript 4.6 Release Candidate 1
Remix 1.2 â€“ The freshest full-stack JS framework in town.
zx 5.1 â€“ Better shell scripting with JS.
Strapi 4.1.0 â€“ Headless Node.js CMS system.
Cypress 9.5.0 â€“ Popular testing system.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Director of Engineering @ ButterCMS (Remote) â€” Working closely with our founder and CEO, youâ€™ll own all technology, deliver on our roadmap, and most importantly, ensure that our customers areÂ successful.
ButterCMS

Senior JavaScript Developer (Remote) â€” Get featured directly to tech companies hiring JavaScript developers right now. Land an interview in as little as 24Â hrs.
Arc

Join the Worldâ€™s Largest Remote Workforce â€” We offer the freedom of freelance with the security of full-time. Start working remotely with the worldâ€™s top clientsÂ today.
Toptal

Stream is Hiring in Boulder, Amsterdam and Remote.
Stream

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Track Down Code Responsible for Polluting the Global Scope â€” You might not want code adding global variables to the window object, and itâ€™s possible to work out where things are goingÂ wrong when itÂ does.

Matteo Mazzarolo

The Basics of package.json â€” Most likely youâ€™ve been working with package.json files for years, but it can pay to refamiliarize yourself with their manyÂ properties.

Gabby T and Marian Villa (NodeScource)

A Deep Dive into React Nativeâ€™s New Architecture â€” A new architecture for React Native is being rolled out in 2022, as described in this post from the React Native team. Here are some independentÂ observations.

Atharva Patil

100+ Fully Native Components for High-Quality Modern Angular UI â€” Get every component you need to build an enterprise-ready app. Kendo UI for Angular can cover any UI requirements your team may have â€” with themes, documentation andÂ more.

Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

ğŸ† Â JavaScript to Know for React â€” A golden oldie weâ€™ve seen doing the rounds again this week. It remains a perfect primer of several key JS features though with examples of features that will help you with React development inÂ particular.

Kent C Dodds

Monorepos Explained â€” A new site that rounds up pretty much anything you need to know about monorepos, and the tools to buildÂ them.

Nrwl

Mimicking Rust's Result Type in 7 Lines of TypeScript
Huy Tran

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

v8n 1.4: A 'Fluent Validation' Library â€” Chain together rules to make validations, e.g. v8n().some.not.uppercase().test("Hello");

Bruno C. Couto

Neat Example of Using a JS Proxy as a Low Code REST Client â€” If youâ€™ve never fiddled with Proxy before, this might sell you on a useÂ case.

David Wells

Project Management for Software Teams Has Never Been Easier â€” Shortcut is fast and intuitive project management built for developers. Delight the scrum gods and try itÂ now.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

TypeIt: A Versatile 'Typewriter Effect' â€” If you need an effect to look like someone is â€˜typingâ€™ on a Web page, this is for you. Alternatively you could create your own from scratch or, if youâ€™re using React, consider Windups.

Alex MacArthur

Marked 4: A Fast Markdown Parser and Compiler â€” Works in the browser or server-side. Demo here to see it inÂ action.

Christopher Jeffrey

Minze: A JavaScript Framework for Native Web Components â€” Based on the latest web component standards and it allows you to build portable component libraries that you can use on anyÂ project.

Sergej Samsonenko

Heart Switch: A Heart-Shaped Toggle Switch Component for React â€” Built with accessibility in mind and a late Valentineâ€™s Day gift for you all, perhaps. You can test it outÂ here.

Anatoliy Gatt

Stream Is Hiring in Boulder, Amsterdam and Remote. Join the Team,Â Today

Stream sponsor

discord-styled-releases: A GitHub Action That Sends Release Messages to Your DiscordÂ Server
Nico Hevia

ğŸ˜Â Well, that's useful!

GitHub has added a handy feature to its custom variant of Markdown so that you can write diagrams directly in Markdown using the same format as Mermaid.js. This is a fantastic way to make your README files more interesting if you have processes that can be outlined by way of a diagram â€“ so check it out.

items.title: The seven figure JavaScript app
items.content:
#â€‹576 â€” February 11, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Apache ECharts 5.3: Open Source JS Visualization Library â€” The release notes go into extensive detail about whatâ€™s in the newest release, including keyframe animations, custom loading animations, and a new SVG renderer with 2-10x improved performance. Lots of demos here too.

Apache Software Foundation

ğŸ¥Š Â Move Over JavaScript? How Some Backend Languages are Coming to the Front-End â€” You might think this is about using WebAssembly to run Python in the browser or something, but no. Itâ€™s about the growing popularity of maintaining a WebSocket connection to a backend process and rendering HTML on the fly from the backend, as seen in modern Elixir and Rails stacks. Food forÂ thought!

GitHub

ButterCMS Melts into Your JS App:: $ butter.post.list() â€” ButterCMS is your content backend. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free for 30Â days.

ButterCMS sponsor

ğŸ§ Â The JS Party Podcast â€” Itâ€™s come to our attention we havenâ€™t linked to the fine JS Party podcast for a fair while, so if you havenâ€™t been listening, thereâ€™s a lot of good stuff to catch up on. Last week they dug into SolidJS, last December covered Svelte, and even had a lawyer on to discuss the legal implications of GitHubÂ Copilot.

The Changelog podcast

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤‘ Few of us have sold a very basic JavaScript app for over $1m to the New York Times. The creator of Wordle has and â–¶ï¸ talks about it on the Syntax podcast.

  • Node.js 17.5.0 has landed with the experimental support for the Fetch API we mentioned last week.

  • The Khronos WebGL Working Group reminds us that WebGL 2.0 is now broadly supported by all major browsers, and to start migrating to it.

  • Popular HTTP client curl has gained a --json option you might find handy.

  • When a JavaScript developer decides to skip React and SPAs and builds a Rails app instead, you can expect a bit of 'spirited discussion'.

  • As promised and on schedule, Vue 3 is now the new default version of Vue.js and vuejs.org has been updated accordingly.

RELEASES:

Vite 2.8.0 â€“ Next gen frontend tooling.
RedwoodJS 0.45.0 â€“ Edge deployable full-stack JS framework.
MikroORM 5 â€“ Data mapper ORM for Node.
AdminJS 5.6 â€“ Admin panel built in Node.js.
npm 8.5.0
Ember.js 4.2.0

ğŸ’» Jobs

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Senior React Engineer @ Nebulab (Remote) â€” Join our distributed team and build high-volume eCommerce applications in a workplace made by developers forÂ developers.
Nebulab

Say Goodbye to the Office Hello to Freedom â€” Thereâ€™s a reason thousands of developers are switching to remote freelance. Join the worldâ€™s top talent network and find outÂ why.
Toptal

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Debugging JavaScript â€” Itâ€™s not deep, but this is an enjoyable and casual walk through the JavaScript debuggingÂ landscape.

Flavio Copes

How the Angular Compiler Works â€” The Angular compiler (known as ngc) is the tool used to compile Angular apps and libraries. This post digs into what it does and how it doesÂ it.

Alex Rickabaugh

Replacing JavaScript Dialogs (Partly) with HTML's <dialog> â€” How to replace JavaScript dialogs, to some extent, with the HTML dialog element providing similar functionality to the alert(), confirm(), and prompt()Â methods.

Mads Stoumann

Join The Big Fix - Fix Vulnerabilities. Earn Swag â€” Earn swag (including t-shirts) for fixing vulnerabilities! Plus, join our fix-a-thon livestream on FebÂ 25.

Snyk sponsor

â–¶Â Â Writing a SPI SD-Card Driver in TypeScript â€” From a live Low Level JavaScript stream comes an interesting (and very long) session that goes deep into the weeds of working at a low level to read data from SDÂ cards.

Low Level JavaScript

An Introduction to Deno: Is It Better than Node? â€” Weâ€™ve mentioned Deno, which comes from Ryan Dahl, much as Node.js originally did, numerous times, but if you havenâ€™t checked it out yet this post covers the key features, as well as where Deno is ahead orÂ behind.

Ayooluwa Isaiah

Writing My Own Build System: Coupling Gulp Concepts with ModernÂ JS â€” The author finds Gulpâ€™s reliance on streams makes it complicated to extend, and shows off a different approach to the same problem using asyncÂ generators.

Wladimir Palant

â–¶Â Â Finite State Machines in Vue 3
Sarah Dayan

Building an Apache ECharts Data Viz Dashboard with Vue 3 and Cube
Ashutosh Singh

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

zx 5.0: Writing Better Shell Scripts in JavaScript â€” Google isnâ€™t slacking, with the fourth major version of zx in a year. Rather than using something like bash to throw together a quick script, zx provides niceties to do the same with JavaScript. v5.0 adds built-in YAMLÂ support.

Google

Pintora: An Extensible Text-to-Diagram Rendering Library â€” A similar idea to the well established Mermaid.js (which has a new version out today, too) but with a different attitude to extensibility as well as no requirement for a headless browser if you're using it from Node. The introduction docs have both visual and codeÂ examples.

Hikerpig

Solidus: The Last eCommerce Back-End Youâ€™ll Ever Need â€” Get the freedom & flexibility to create unique, custom-built shopping experiences without makingÂ compromises.

Solidus sponsor

Griffel: CSS-in-JS with Ahead-of-Time Compilation â€” From Microsoft, another CSS-in-JS option. This one boasts near-zero runtime, SSR support, and styles defined with JS objects, among otherÂ features.

Microsoft

Fable 3.7: A Mature F# to JavaScript Compiler â€” F# is a â€˜functional firstâ€™ language from the MS/.NET stable and Iâ€™m always struck by just how nicely it reads. If you fancy giving it a go for building things for the frontend, check out this online REPL which has some samples to tinkerÂ with, including a wee Mario (above).

Alfonso GarcÃ­a-Caro and contributors

puppeteer-to-playwright: Puppeteer to Playwright Conversion Script â€” If you want to migrate between the two popular browser automation systems, this couldÂ help.

Checkly

Project Management for Software Teams Has Never BeenÂ Easier

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

P42 JavaScript Assistant: Refactoring Hints and Automation for VSÂ Code â€” A Visual Studio Code extension that brings 67 automated refactorings and quick fixes for common JS, TS and React issues to your editor, so you can clean things up even before you hit your normal linter, perhaps.

P42 Project

Mineflayer 4.0: Build Minecraft Bots in JavaScript â€” GitHubÂ repo.
Andrew Kelley

React Components: 15+ Extensive Libraries to Consider
Alex Ivanovs

ğŸŒğŸŒ Â SunCalc 1.9: Tiny Library for Calculating Sun/Moon Positions and Phases
Vladimir Agafonkin
items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹576 â€” February 11, 2022


UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web



JavaScript Weekly




  








  
  
Apache ECharts 5.3: Open Source JS Visualization Library â€” The release notes go into extensive detail about whatâ€™s in the newest release, including keyframe animations, custom loading animations, and a new SVG renderer with 2-10x improved performance. Lots of demos here too.
Apache Software Foundation 


  
  
ğŸ¥Š Â Move Over JavaScript? How Some Backend Languages are Coming to the Front-End â€” You might think this is about using WebAssembly to run Python in the browser or something, but no. Itâ€™s about the growing popularity of maintaining a WebSocket connection to a backend process and rendering HTML on the fly from the backend, as seen in modern Elixir and Rails stacks. Food forÂ thought!
GitHub 


  
  
ButterCMS Melts into Your JS App:: $ butter.post.list() â€” ButterCMS is your content backend. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free for 30Â days.
ButterCMS sponsor


  
  
ğŸ§ Â The JS Party Podcast â€” Itâ€™s come to our attention we havenâ€™t linked to the fine JS Party podcast for a fair while, so if you havenâ€™t been listening, thereâ€™s a lot of good stuff to catch up on. Last week they dug into SolidJS, last December covered Svelte, and even had a lawyer on to discuss the legal implications of GitHubÂ Copilot.
The Changelog podcast


IN BRIEF:
ğŸ¤‘ Few of us have sold a very basic JavaScript app for over $1m to the New York Times. The creator of Wordle has and â–¶ï¸ talks about it on the Syntax podcast.
Node.js 17.5.0 has landed with the experimental support for the Fetch API we mentioned last week.
The Khronos WebGL Working Group reminds us that WebGL 2.0 is now broadly supported by all major browsers, and to start migrating to it.
Popular HTTP client curl has gained a --json option you might find handy.
When a JavaScript developer decides to skip React and SPAs and builds a Rails app instead, you can expect a bit of 'spirited discussion'.
As promised and on schedule, Vue 3 is now the new default version of Vue.js and vuejs.org has been updated accordingly.
RELEASES:
Vite 2.8.0 â€“ Next gen frontend tooling.
RedwoodJS 0.45.0 â€“ Edge deployable full-stack JS framework.
MikroORM 5 â€“ Data mapper ORM for Node.
AdminJS 5.6 â€“ Admin panel built in Node.js.
npm 8.5.0
Ember.js 4.2.0





ğŸ’» Jobs





  
JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
  
X-Team 
  


  
Senior React Engineer @ Nebulab (Remote) â€” Join our distributed team and build high-volume eCommerce applications in a workplace made by developers forÂ developers.
  
Nebulab

Toptal

â–¶Â Â Writing a SPI SD-Card Driver in TypeScript â€” From a live Low Level JavaScript stream comes an interesting (and very long) session that goes deep into the weeds of working at a low level to read data from SDÂ cards.
Low Level JavaScript

Ayooluwa Isaiah

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

items.title: Get decorating with Babel 7.17.0
items.content:
#â€‹575 â€” February 4, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Writing a Printer Driver in JavaScript â€” â€œWriting a printer driver in JavaScript sounds ridiculous,â€ starts the author, and while the definition of â€˜driverâ€™ is arguable here (it's more a filter?), this is nonetheless an interesting storyÂ andÂ solution.

Dan Pastusek

Babel 7.17.0 Released â€” Now that the decorators proposal has stabilized, Babel includes parse and transform support for them, if you want to get playing. The â€˜vâ€™ flag proposal for regexes has also beenÂ implemented.

Babel Team

ButterCMS Melts into Your JS App:
$ butter.post.list() â€” ButterCMS is your content backend. Enable your marketing team to update website + app content without needing you. Try the #1 rated Headless CMS for your JS app today. Free for 30Â days.

ButterCMS sponsor

The Fetch API is Coming to Node Core (and Why to Care) â€” Support for the Fetch API (as commonly used browser-side for fetching resources) has been merged into Node.js and will be available behind a --experimental-fetch flag until, hopefully, being enabled by default in NodeÂ 18+.

Yavor Georgiev

Memory Leaks: The Forgotten Side of Web Performance â€” An even-handed take on the importance of memory leaks, even though the â€œeffort-to-payoff ratioâ€ is often seen as â€œdisappointinglyÂ highâ€.

Nolan Lawson

IN BRIEF:

  • V8 v9.9 is on the way, with a focus on improvements to Intl.

  • A big new monthly update for VS Code with a JS debugging improvement that lets you exclude certain callers from pausing at breakpoints.

  • The npm registry is now requiring maintainers of the top 100 npm packages to use 2FA. This policy will extend to more maintainers over time.

  • Using [].join(', ') to join lists of strings? Eric Clemmons has a nifty alternative to consider.

  • Dan Abramov tries to sell us on Sublime Text versus VS Code.

  • Jest is a very popular JS testing framework associated with Facebook yet allegedly no-one at Facebook has worked on Jest for years.

RELEASES:

MDX 2.0 â€“ Markdown + JSX = â¤ï¸
Partytown 0.3 â€“ Take third party scripts off the main thread.
Mongoose 6.2.0 â€“ MongoDB object modelling library.
Recoil 0.6 â€“ Alternative React state management.
Commander.js 9.0 â€“ Node CLI framework.
CKEditor 5 v32.0 â€“ Rich text editor framework.
ESLint 8.8.0

ğŸ’» Jobs

Senior Web Developer (Node/ReactJS) - Remote â€” Millions get inspired and plan adventures with our apps. To help us make komoot.com the place to go to plan outdoor adventures, weâ€™re looking for a one of a kind Web Developer to join ourÂ team.
Komoot

Senior JavaScript Engineer â€” Join our dev team and help develop, test, document and maintain our JS driven webÂ applications.
Civey

Toptal: The Worldâ€™s Top Companies at Your Fingertips â€” We connect developers like you with exclusive clients that include Fortune 500 companies and Silicon Valley startups. ApplyÂ now.
Toptal

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Speeding Up VS Code Extensions in 2022 â€” One of those â€˜niche but interestingâ€™ posts that digs into the underlying architecture of VS Code and a must-read for anyone considering making their ownÂ extension.

Jason Williams

â–¶Â Â Your Weekly Source for Conversations on the Art & Practice of Software â€” Ben Popper, Cassidy Williams & Ceora Ford explore what it means to work in software, and how code is reshaping ourÂ world.

The Stack Overflow Podcast sponsor

Improving JavaScript Bundle Performance With Code-Splitting â€” Looks at the benefits and caveats of code-splitting and how page performance and load times can be improved by dynamically loading expensive, non-critical JavaScriptÂ bundles.

Adrian Bece

What Web Frameworks Solve And How To Do Without Them â€” Dives deep into a few technical features that are common across frameworks, and explains how some of the different frameworks implement them and whatÂ theyÂ cost.

Noam Rosenthal

Use Streams to Build High-Performing Node Apps â€” Using the stream module in Node.js to yourÂ advantage.

Deepal Jayasekara

Connect a Chatbot to Popular Messaging Channels â€” Learn the easy way to connect a chatbot to Telegram, Messenger, Twilio, Smooch, Vonage, Slack, and MicrosoftÂ Teams.

Botpress sponsor

How To Create, Test and Deploy a SPA with Vue 3, Vite and Pinia
Andrei Rusu

â–¶Â Â The Story of React (in 10 Minutes)
uiÂ·dev

Preventing Smooth Scrolling with JavaScript
Kilian Valkhof

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Sigma 2.2: A Graph Drawing Library â€” A mature library (we first linked it in 2015!) aimed at use cases where you have giant graphs containing thousands of nodes and edges that you need to render quickly. Some good examples here. GitHubÂ repo.

Alexis Jacomy

A-Frame 1.3: A Framework for Building WebVR Experiences â€” A web framework for building virtual reality experiences that work on Vive, Rift, Quest, as well as desktop and mobile platforms, including in the browser (as the demos hereÂ show).

A-Frame VR Team

Electron 17 Released â€” The popular cross-platform desktop app framework gets key dependency bumps with Chromium 98 support, Node 16.13.0, and V8Â 9.8.

Michaela Laurencin and Keeley Hammond

Pulumi: Developer-First Infrastructure with JavaScript

Pulumi sponsor

Hotkey 2.0: Trigger an Action on an Element When a 'Hotkey' isÂ Pressed â€” Use Hotkey, set the data-hotkey attribute on your elements, and you get keyboard shortcuts. v2.0 justÂ dropped. If it's good enough for GitHub, it's good enough forÂ us!

GitHub

imask.js 6.4.0: A Vanilla JavaScript Input Mask â€” Rather than validate the syntax of input fields, how about preventing users from even entering invalidÂ values?

imaskjs

lite-youtube: A Web Component That Renders YouTube Embeds Faster â€” Itâ€™s the Shadow DOM web component version of Paul Irishâ€™s lite-youtube-embed, with keyboard accessibility and some other niceÂ features.

Justin Ribeiro

ğŸ˜Â And finally..

WebVM.io takes you straight to a Web-based 'server-less' virtual Linux environment running directly in your browser. It's powered by the JavaScript and WebAssembly-based CheerpX x86 virtualization engine. While it's not a JavaScript project exactly, it's a neat demonstration of how far Web technology has come. It has Node v10.24.0 'installed' if you want to try that, but beware it takes a good 20 seconds to load on my machine.

Here's a write-up about how it works, if you want to learn more.

Note: Probably one for desktop users only due to the resources and performance needed.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
